metadata.case_name: Petitioner (Textbook Publisher) v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioner carries on business of printing, publishing and selling textbooks for Primary, Middle and Higher Secondary classes in Madhya Pradesh.
On 1st November 1956, new State of Madhya Pradesh formed comprising Mahakoshal, Madhya Bharat (excluding some areas), Bhopal and Vindhya Pradesh under States Reorganisation Act, 1956.
School education divided into Primary (Classes I-V), Middle (VI-VIII), Higher Secondary (IX-XI). Primary and Middle treated similarly, distinct from Higher Secondary.

Prior to reorganisation, Primary and Middle education regulated by State Government in Mahakoshal and Madhya Bharat; prescribed courses, syllabi followed by private schools for recognition and grants.
State Government prescribed 29 textbooks printed/published by it for Primary/Middle classes, no statutory authority but accepted for grants/recognition.

Society 'Madhya Pradesh Pathya Pustak Rachna Avam Shaikshanik Anusandhan Nigam' (Text Books Corporation) formed by State Government, controlled by it, registered under MP Societies Act 1959, loan of Rs.15 lacs provided.

Until end of 1970-71, 29 State-published textbooks continued; from 1971-72, new courses/syllabi notified 18 May 1971, Text Books Corporation printed 28 new textbooks prescribed by notification 21 May 1971.
Notification 21 May 1971 called them 'nationalized textbooks'; for other subjects, private books allowed if conforming to prior syllabi.
For 1972-73, notification 10 May 1972 prescribed same 28 revised textbooks; later 36 textbooks by order 23 March 1973 (not challenged).
Higher Secondary regulated by MP Secondary Education Act 1951 (Mahakoshal), MP Bharat Secondary Education Act Samvat 2007 (Madhya Bharat), repealed by Act of 1959.
Act of 1959: Board of Secondary Education incorporated; ss.18-19 constituted Text Books Committee of independent experts to select textbooks.
Board prescribed textbooks in languages (English, Hindi, Marathi, Sanskrit) claiming implied power; recommended others.

MP Madhyamik Shiksha Adhiniyam 1965 (Act of 1965) repealed Act 1959; Board powers in s.8 include prescribe courses for Secondary, advise on Middle; Committees of Courses recommend syllabi/textbooks per Regulations 1965.
Board procedure: Publishers register, submit textbooks per specs; anonymized review by 3 reviewers, then Committee of Courses; Chairman selects per resolution 12 Oct 1971.

Board prescribed language textbooks (except General English, Tamil for IX-X); recommended for Civics (notif 5 Apr 1972), Economics (25 Apr 1972), Physics (26 Apr 1972), Chemistry (17 May 1972). Petitioner's books rejected.
MP Prathamik, Middle School Tatha Madhyamik Shiksha Pathya Pustakon Sambandhi Vyavastha Adhiniyam, 1973 (Act 1973) enacted, came into force 23 Mar 1973.
Board notification 28 Mar 1973: Continued prior textbooks/recommendations for 1976 exam except some languages.
State notification 24 May 1973 approved textbooks on Botany, Zoology, History, Elements of Commerce, English for 1976 exam, recited consultation with Board.
Petitioner filed writ under Art 32 challenging prescriptions and Act 1973.

legal_issues.text: Whether 28 textbooks prescribed by State Govt via notifications 21 May 1971 and 10 May 1972 prior to Act 1973 were validly prescribed and qualify under s.4(2).
Whether Board had statutory power to prescribe language textbooks prior to Act 1973.
Whether recommended textbooks on Civics, Economics, Physics, Chemistry qualify as prescribed under s.4(2).
Whether notification 24 May 1973 valid without prior consultation with Board as per proviso to s.4(1).
Whether s.4(1) and (3) of Act 1973 violate Arts. 19(1)(g) and 14 by conferring unguided power on State Govt to prescribe textbooks.

petitioner_arguments.text: State had no statutory authority to prescribe 28 textbooks pre-Act 1973; notifications invalid, do not qualify under s.4(2).
Board had no statutory power to prescribe language textbooks; invalid, do not qualify under s.4(2); Board notif 28 Mar 1973 ineffective as not by State.
Board notifications merely recommended, not prescribed textbooks on Civics etc.; notif 28 Mar 1973 ineffective.
Notif 24 May 1973 invalid for lack of prior consultation with Board.
S.4 imposes unreasonable restrictions without proper machinery for selection; unguided discretion violates Art 19(1)(g) and Art 14.

respondent_arguments.text: State could prescribe 28 textbooks via executive power under Art 162; no infringement of rights.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art 162; Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v. State of Punjab

respondent_arguments.text: Board had implied power to prescribe language textbooks as part of courses of instruction.
Recommended textbooks continued via notif 28 Mar 1973.
Notif 24 May 1973 followed consultation via Chairman/Committees representing Board.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Proviso s.4(1); Board resolution 12 Oct 1971; s.15 Act 1965

respondent_arguments.text: S.4 guided by objective of uniform high-quality textbooks; no violation of Arts 14,19(1)(g).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v. State of Punjab

court_reasoning.text: State could prescribe 28 textbooks pre-Act via executive power under Art 162 as education in List II; no prejudice to publishers' rights as no vested right in prescription.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Publishers have only chance/prospect, not right, to have books prescribed.

court_reasoning.text: Board had no express/implied power to prescribe language textbooks; courses can be prescribed without specific textbooks.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power to prescribe courses does not imply power to prescribe textbooks.

court_reasoning.text: Recommendations not prescriptions; no binding obligation; notif 28 Mar 1973 by Board ineffective under s.4(1).
No prior consultation with Board (Chairman/Committees not Board); notif 24 May 1973 invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proviso mandatory; recital shifts burden but facts show no Board consultation.

court_reasoning.text: S.4(1),(3) not violative of Art 19(1)(g) as no right infringed (per Rai Jawaya); guided by policy of best quality textbooks, not arbitrary under Art 14.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object provides guidance; State Govt trustable, rules under s.8 possible.

holdings.text: 28 Text Books Corporation textbooks validly prescribed pre-Act via executive power; qualify under s.4(2).
Board language textbook prescriptions ultra vires; do not qualify under s.4(2).
Recommended textbooks not prescribed; do not qualify under s.4.
Notification 24 May 1973 invalid for lack of prior Board consultation.
S.4(1),(3) Act 1973 constitutional; does not violate Arts 14, 19(1)(g).

precedents_cited.case_name: Rai Sahib Ram Jawaya Kapur v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: State executive power to enter textbook business/print without legislation if no rights infringed; no right in publishers for prescription.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Thakur Bharat Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Reiterates Rai Jawaya: executive action valid if no rights infringed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bennett Coleman Co. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Executive action prejudicing rights needs legislative authority.

precedents_cited.case_name: Swadeshi Cotton Mills v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Recital of condition precedent raises presumption; burden on challenger.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administrator for Union Territory of Delhi

precedents_cited.relevance: Discretion in Govt less prone to abuse than in minor official.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ; executive power; fundamental rights to trade/equality; education state subject.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Secondary Education Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Board incorporation, powers, Text Books Committee.

statutes_cited.name: Madhya Pradesh Madhyamik Shiksha Adhiniyam, 1965
statutes_cited.relevance: Board powers, Chairman duties, regulations; repealed 1959 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Board of Secondary Education, Madhya Pradesh Regulations, 1965
statutes_cited.relevance: Committees of Courses recommend syllabi/textbooks; recognition conditions.

statutes_cited.name: MP Prathamik, Middle School Tatha Madhyamik Shiksha Pathya Pustakon Sambandhi Vyavastha Adhiniyam, 1973
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of textbook; syllabi; prescription by State/Board; exclusivity; central to challenge.

outcome.summary: Court upheld validity of 28 pre-Act textbooks prescribed by State executive power and constitutionality of s.4 Act 1973 against Arts 14/19(1)(g); held Board had no power to prescribe language textbooks and recommendations not prescriptions; struck down 24 May 1973 notification for lack of prior Board consultation.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that 24 May 1973 notification invalid; no broader relief as challenges to Act and prior prescriptions rejected.

key_quotes.text: "there is no right in a publisher that any of the books printed and published by him should be prescribed as text books by the school authorities"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding no vested right in prescription, upholding executive/statutory power.

key_quotes.text: "Such chances are incidental to all trades and businesses and there is no fundamental right guaranteeing them."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.relevance: From Rai Jawaya, applied to reject Art 19(1)(g) challenge.

key_quotes.text: "The power to select and prescribe text books is thus not an unguided and unfettered power... but it is a power which is confined and embanked within limits by the object and purpose for which it is conferred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects Art 14 challenge by finding implied guidance in statute's object.
